Prepared by Dr. Badr bin Nasser Al-Badr, Associate Professor, Department of Qur’an and Its Sciences, College of Usul al-Din, Imam University

In the Name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful

Introduction: All praise is due to Allah; we praise Him, seek His help, and ask for His forgiveness. We seek refuge with Allah from the evils of our souls and the bad deeds of our actions. Whomever Allah guides, none can misguide, and whomever He leaves astray, none can guide. I bear witness that there is no deity except Allah alone with no partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger. {O you who have believed, fear Allah as He should be feared and do not die except as Muslims.} [Al-Imran: 102]  {O mankind, fear your Lord, who created you from one soul and created from it its mate and dispersed from both of them many men and women. Chapter Two: Definition of Security (Aman), its Pillars, and Formulas.
Ibn Manzur said: "Ista'mana ilayhi: He entered into his security (Aman). And ammanahu (he granted him security) and amanahu. Al-Ma'man: The place of safety. Al-Amin: The one seeking protection to be safe for himself" (1). Al-Jawhari said: "Al-Aman and Al-Amanah are synonymous. And amantu ghayri (I granted security to another) comes from amn and aman" (2).
Aman relies on two fundamental pillars: The Grantor (Mu'min) and the Seeker (Musta'man). The Musta'man is the one who requests security for himself to enter Muslim lands for a known period. The Grantor (Mu'min) is the one who gives security. The basis for this is that it is the Imam or his deputy, because he looks into what serves the interest of the Muslims. It is also permissible for the Grantor to be an individual subject from among the competent Muslims, whether male or female; the free and the slave are equal in this regard. This is the view of the majority of scholars. Abu Hanifa disagreed regarding the security granted by a slave, holding that it is not valid unless he is authorized to fight.
As for the formulas of Aman, they are not restricted to a specific wording, nor does it have a special term. Rather, any utterance that conveys the intended meaning suffices, whether explicit, such as "I grant you protection," "I secure you," "No harm shall come to you," "No panic," or "No fear" and the like; or metaphorically with intention, such as saying: "Be as you wish," or "You are as you like." It is also valid via writing, correspondence, and the like (3).

The basis for Aman is His saying, the Exalted: {And if any one of the polytheists seeks your protection, then grant him protection so that he may hear the words of Allah. Then deliver him to his place of safety. That is because they are a people who do not know} (1).
Ibn Jarir al-Tabari said: "The Exalted mentions to His Prophet: And if one of the polytheists - whom I commanded you to fight and kill after the passing of the sacred months - seeks your security, O Muhammad, in order to hear the words of Allah from you, which is the Quran that Allah revealed to him; [THEN GRANT HIM PROTECTION] He says: Then secure him {SO THAT HE MAY HEAR THE WORDS OF ALLAH} and you recite it to him. {THEN DELIVER HIM TO HIS PLACE OF SAFETY} He says: Then return him, after he has heard the words of Allah, if he refuses to become Muslim and is not admonished by what you recited to him of Allah's words, so that he is secure in: [HIS PLACE OF SAFETY] He says: To where he is safe from you and from those in your obedience, until he rejoins his abode and his people among the polytheists" (2).
Ibn Kathir said: "The Exalted says to His Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: {AND IF ANY ONE OF THE POLYTHEISTS} whom I commanded you to fight and made lawful for you their lives and wealth [SEEKS YOUR PROTECTION] meaning: seeks security from you, then answer his request until he hears the words of Allah, meaning: the Quran, you read it to him and mention to him

So whoever betrays a Muslim (by violating his pledge), upon him is the curse of Allah, the angels, and all people; no obligatory nor voluntary deed will be accepted from him." Chapter Four: The Difference between Security (Aman), Dhimmah, and Truce (Hudnah).
Ibn al-Qayyim - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - has valuable words on the difference between these three terms and the rulings entailed by them, where he says: "The disbelievers are either people of war (Ahl Harb) or people of covenant (Ahl 'Ahd). The people of covenant are of three categories: People of Dhimmah (Protection/Citizenship), People of Hudnah (Truce), and People of Aman (Security). Jurists have dedicated a chapter for each category, saying: Chapter of Truce, Chapter of Security, Chapter of the Contract of Dhimmah. The terms 'Dhimmah' and 'Ahd' (Covenant) originally encompass all of them. Likewise, the term 'Sulh' (Peace/Reconciliation), for Dhimmah is of the same genus as the terms 'Ahd' and 'Aqd' (Contract). Their saying: 'This is in the Dhimmah of so-and-so' originates from this, meaning: in his covenant and contract, i.e., he bound him by the contract and pact. Then it came to be used for everything from which a right can be taken, whether obligated by his contract or without his contract. Similarly, the term 'Sulh' is general for every reconciliation, covering the reconciliation of Muslims with each other and their reconciliation with disbelievers. However, in the terminology of many jurists, 'Ahl al-Dhimmah' became an expression for those who pay Jizyah. These have a perpetual covenant (Dhimmah). They have made a covenant with the Muslims that the ruling of Allah and His Messenger shall apply to them, as they reside in the Abode (Dar) where the ruling of Allah and His Messenger applies. This is unlike the People of Truce (Ahl al-Hudnah), for they have reconciled with the Muslims to remain in their own abode (Dar), whether the reconciliation is for money or without money;

These are called People of Covenant (Ahl al-'Ahd), People of Reconciliation (Ahl al-Sulh), and People of Truce (Ahl al-Hudnah). As for the Musta'man (one granted security), he is the one who comes to the lands of the Muslims without settling there. These are of four types: messengers, merchants, and seekers of asylum so that Islam and the Quran may be presented to them; if they wish, they enter into it, and if they wish, they return to their lands; and [fourthly] those seeking a need such as a visit or otherwise. The ruling for these is that they are not forced to emigrate, they are not killed, Jizyah is not taken from them, and Islam and the Quran are presented to the asylum seeker among them. If he enters into it, then so be it; if he prefers to rejoin his place of safety, he is escorted to it and is not interfered with before reaching it. Once he reaches his place of safety, he returns to being a Harbi (at war) as he was" (1).

If they can do without them, they should be expelled like the people of Khaybar. There is a dispute in this issue which is not appropriate to discuss here. The intended point here is that if people need millers and bakers, this is of two types: First: That they need their craftsmanship, like those who grind and bake for households; these deserve wages, and when needed, they can only demand the standard wage (Ajr al-Mithl) like other artisans. Second: That they need the production and sale, needing someone to buy wheat, grind it, bake it, and sell it as bread for people's needs..." (1). Sheikh Muhammad bin Uthaymeen said: "I agree that we do not have 'Ahl al-Dhimmah' [in the classical sense], because Ahl al-Dhimmah are those who submit to the rulings of Islam and pay the Jizyah, and this has been missing for a long time. text: Section Six: The Duty of Protected Persons (Musta'mins) in Muslim Lands. As for the rights obligatory upon them towards the Muslims who granted them safety in their homes, I summarize them as follows: Consideration of Muslims' feelings and respect for their rituals. They must observe the prestige of the Islamic State under whose protection and care they shade themselves. It is not permissible for them to insult Islam, its Messenger, or its Book, nor to promote their beliefs and ideas or spread corruption among Muslims. It is not permissible for them to display the drinking of alcohol, eating of pork, and other things prohibited in the religion of Islam, let alone selling and trading them, because of the corruption this causes to Islamic society. They must also not display eating and drinking during the days of Ramadan and the like, out of consideration for the feelings of Muslims. They must also adhere to the regulations and laws of the Muslim State which it organizes for the individuals of its people and applies to them. It is not permissible for them to violate or transgress them. If they violate them, they are deterred and punished with what the Muslim ruler or his deputy sees fit (1).
